Starting Position: Begin on hands and knees, wrists under shoulders, knees under hips. Spread fingers wide, press palms firmly into the mat.
Alignment: Exhale, lift knees off floor, gradually straighten legs, create inverted V-shape.

Legs and Feet: Keep knees slightly bent if needed, press heels toward floor.
Hips and Pelvis: Lift sitting bones up, engage core for stability.
Shoulders and Arms: Rotate upper arms outward, broaden collarbones, press palms down.

Head and Neck: Gaze between arms, lengthen neck, relax shoulders away from ears.
Breathing: Maintain smooth, steady breaths, inhale to lengthen spine, exhale to deepen stretch.
Modifications: Use forearms for support if wrists hurt, bend knees generously for tight hamstrings.
Duration: Hold for 5-10 breaths or longer, repeat as desired.
Transitions: Exhale, lower knees to floor, rest in Child's Pose or another comfortable position.

Stretches and Strengthens: Engages and stretches the spine, hamstrings, calves, shoulders, and hands while strengthening the arms, shoulders, and legs. Improves Posture: Lengthens the spine and strengthens the muscles supporting it, aiding in better posture. Increases Circulation: Enhances blood flow throughout the body, including to the brain, due to the inversion. Relieves Tension: Alleviates tension and stress, particularly in the back, shoulders, and neck. Energizing: Serves as a transitional pose, boosting energy and vitality in the body and mind.

High Blood Pressure: Caution advised or avoidance for those with uncontrolled high blood pressure due to potential elevation during inversion. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Requires caution or modification for individuals with wrist injuries or carpal tunnel syndrome. Pregnancy: Pregnant women should be cautious, especially in later stages, and avoid full inversions unless modified. Recent Injury: Those with recent injuries to the back, shoulders, arms, or wrists should avoid or modify the pose. Eye Conditions: Individuals with certain eye conditions, like detached retina or glaucoma, should avoid inversions due to increased intraocular pressure.\n\n
